author: Katie Dickinson
title: Brexit will be 'calamitous' for the North East's NHS if EU doctors leave, senior medic warns
text:
News Brexit will be 'calamitous' for the North East's NHS if EU doctors leave, senior medic warns Dr George Rae said losing European Union doctors would 'pour boiling oil on the already troubled waters' of the NHS Share Dr George Rae from Whitley Bay (Photo: Newcastle Chronicle) Share Get daily   
Brexit will have a “calamitous” effect on the North East’s NHS services if the future of EU doctors working here is not assured, a top health official has warned. 
Following the triggering of Article 50, the British Medical Association’s (BMA) North East chair Dr George Rae has called on the government to grant permanent residency to EU doctors working in the region. 
The move follows a BMA survey which revealed four in ten doctors working in the UK who qualified in European Economic Area (EEA) countries are considering leaving in the wake of Brexit. An EU flag flying in front of the Houses of Parliament (Photo: PA) 
Whitley Bay GP Dr Rae said losing those doctors, which would account for around 7% of the medical workforce in the North East, would be “pouring boiling oil on the already troubled waters” of the NHS. 
He said: “With the NHS at breaking point and facing crippling staff shortages in many areas, losing more doctors would seriously impact patient care.” 
Last month, EU doctors working in the NHS gave stark warnings about the future in a BMA study on the impact of the UK’s Brexit vote. 
When asked whether they were considering leaving the UK as a result of last year’s referendum result, 42% of those surveyed conceded that they were, while 23% said they were unsure. Dr George Rae 
On a scale of one to 10, European doctors said they feel significantly less committed to working in the UK in light of the EU referendum result. From an average of nine out of 10, commitment dropped to six out of 10. 
Dr Rae has called on the Prime Minister to “control the impact of Brexit on the NHS and protect patient care across the country by granting permanent residence to EEA nationals working in the UK”. Read More
